commentBody: Too easy for a Thursday, and a pretty weak theme.

I know that the clue for 3D is technically correct, but really, it's per the actual songwriter, who we just lost in September, Kris Kristofferson. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ahpIirW0svY I will admit, though, that Janis's version delivered a great royalty paycheck to Kris for the rest of his natural life.

A fourTOnate puzzle for a Thursday.

Now if only the TO-less versions
had deep meanings themselves,
or maybe could be read backwards.

Thanks, Joe.
Not my favorite. I wasted some time trying to put "to" in a rebus in a few places.

I was clued in TO the constructor’s wavelength for this one, thanks in part to my soon to be five year old grandson, whose interest in Mario Kart familiarized me with TOADETTE.  My only real hiccups were itnerd before ITGURU and gator before EGRET.  Rave party for CRITIC and made do for TOUPEE made me smile.  I did think the gray squares made the theme pretty easy to spot, and I caught on at 3D’s reference to Me And Bobby McGee.
Quick, but I liked it.

MR BILL (1996-2014). Cat extraordinaire. 

My father’s name was Bill and he was a bit put out (why did you name your cat after me?!). 

I didn’t!  I named him after the lesser known brother of my favorite baseball player (Cal Ripken). 

He started out as Billy, but he was the boy-cat with two girl cats, and over time his name got gendered: Mr. Bill. 

He was the peacemaker among them. What a cat.
Gonna guess that most of NYT readers are NOT OKAY today.

Anything to get me away from thinking about the country is good. I liked this tricky puzzle. Fun theme and cluing was clever. Especially love the reference to the Velvet Fog TORME. And I remember 15 years ago when Gochujang was impossible to find in Sunset Park Brooklyn. Now they have a bunch of flavors.
Nice puzzle but I hit a snag at 23A.  I have heard of et alia but not alii. Is that the plural? Live and learn.
Supporting the strike.  Not playing

At first I was hoping the theme fill words would be strategically positioned around each other. 

NOTHING to the left of LOSE
BRINGS above SPEED
COME below THE WIRE
GET to right of THE POINT

Might have been a bit more difficult and surprising once discovered. 

But, noodle nuggets are a dime a dozen. I’m always amazed by our constructor’s creations and ability to execute their vision, just the way they are. That goes double on Thursdays.  

Great puzzle. Thanks, Joe Deeney!
Fast and fun.
can someone  please explain the mini about an L after 7 across making two timely words???
Oklahoma is not in the Midwest!  It's west of Arkansas and further south than Kentucky.

I find so much of this puzzle, which I did complete, so foreign as to be beyond bizarre. The makers of the NYT puzzles seem to think that people with a very au courant hip knowledge of cultural terms should be the solvers. That’s far from fair to the average capable puzzler. I’ve been completing NYT crosswords for 56 years but feel increasingly discouraged. Unfortunately, I sense that the editorial staff couldn’t care less.
Thank goodness for the editor. I couldn't imagine trying this puzzle without the [T][O]s shaded

Outstanding. Ingenious. *Fun*. A great Thursday. And most importantly a balm and a distraction from… events. For those of you Stateside doing it tough today, warmest wishes from the South Pacific. We feel for you.

This was a really good Thursday puzzle.  Ran a little quick at 14:16, but still felt it was the perfect mix of challenge without frustration or gimmick.  The 'theme' was apparent once enough of the crosses were there and I had a good idea what the clue 'should' be.  Some really good cluing that brought freshness to standard fill like EERIE, ODE, and APE.  Also, ERSATZ is a cool word.  Only natick I could see would be TORME and GEER, but I made a lucky guess first try.

I know that the WII and the Switch were both game consoles, but I must've blinked when something called a WIIU existed, because I've never heard of it. But, OK, fine. There are lots of things I've never heard of.

However - I strongly protest against SUHWEET! It's not a word; it's not a name; it's not an initialism; nor is it an acronym. It simply doesn't belong in a game with the word "word" in its name.

And another thing: Janis' version of the lyric was clearly "nothin' left to lose", not NOTHING(LEFT TO)LOSE. If you're going to clue it using Janis Joplin's name, then the answer shouldn't have that "G" in it.

Surprisingly easy, for me, for a Thursday! A dreaded compass direction was in there, and WIIU confused the heck out of me when it came together in crosses until I remembered the clue, but the rest came easily. I do like puzzles with the diversions (I think my fave of this sort was that neat roller coaster one a while back!) but this was very simple and my fastest Thursday ever. BROSPEAK was cleverly clued, and shaky start gave me a laugh and memories of my teenage years in NZ! Thanks!

The added benefit letting the kids in your life drag you downstairs to watch them play Mario Kart?

You get to plop in TOADETTE without a second thought.

The main benefit, of course, is that you get to escape from the adults for a while.
Ten-euro bills pink? Mine are definitely more orange-y.

Off to a good start when I noticed BRING UP TO SPEED, but I my brain decided that was enough as I couldn’t get the others, so frustrating,  but there was still a lot to enjoy  in this clever Thursday puzzle.  It must have been very difficult to construct, so appreciate Joe’s efforts.
Surprised and disappointed that the vulgar “WAP” clue/answer was approved by the editors even though it’s a popular song.
Fun puzzle. Probably too easy for a Thursday but some fun cluing (made do, noodle nuggets.). I tire, though, of the constant references to gaming in puzzles.

Give me some Janis, 
which gives me a little Jerry,
and my morning is brightened.

Fun one.

Liked noodle nuggets,

(and Deb, yep, my kids faves were “nuggets”
which are also called radiatore).

Happy Thursday all!

Wow. The NYT allowed WAP?. Kudos. 
A good Thursday, even if the clues were on the slightly easier side. I enjoyed the theme once I got it. 

Waiting for my flight to start my holiday. Definitely in need of a break.

Whew. And Wow. Typical slow start for me, but a great moment when I finally caught on (thanks to Janis Joplin). Still took a bit of pondering to work out all the other theme answers, but that was just one nice 'aha' moment after another. 

And... this is just one amazing piece of construction. Had to be quite a challenge to work in those four symmetrically placed theme answers with the added restriction of the adjacent 'TOs.' That just has to add another level of restriction to working out the grid and theme answer placements. 

And, a roundabout search led to another clever puzzle. That one was all in the clues. I'll put it in a reply.

..

Great mix of easy and tough clues. WiiiU, Toadette, and alii were new to me! As a lifeLONG solver I love learning new words and cultural references from the puzzle every day. I kind of sympathize with folks who don’t know current references to games, music, and whatnot, but then again, what about younger solvers who’ve never heard of The Waltons (Will Geer), Jane Eyre, Janis Joplin, Gulliver’s Travels (Lilliputian), or even old episodes of The Simpsons? I think a good puzzle is a pleasant mix of the old and the new so that we don’t get stuck with predictable clues and answers. I will admit, though, that when I saw “suhweet” I thought, “Oh boy! There will be complaints! Lol!”

If anyone else is trying to take a break from the news and would like something to amuse themselves with in their downtime, I highly recommend the Sunday, July 25, 1999 puzzle from Charles M. Deber.  It was mentioned last week by @David Connell (I think?).  I needed a little extra puzzling this morning and found it incredibly clever.  It ranks up there with my all-time favorites.

Fun theme! Caught on right away to the theme clues, which always helps me start my day feeling like a genuis!

Though, ERSATZ is new to me and I had TOUSLE instead of TOUPEE, so I got stuck in the NE corner until I did a look up.
Oh no!
Got completely stuck on bottom right as I had the phrase as down TO THE WIRE, which is the common parlance for me. Otherwise got the trick fairly quickly and a fun full.

When I cracked the theme maybe two-thirds the way through, it brought a big smile, a big “Hah!”, and a big “Great idea!”  That’s a very good theme, in my book.

But the good didn’t stop there:
•	Every theme answer was solid, packed a punch.
•	Loveliness showed up in the fill: ERSATZ, TROPE, CONDIMENT, and even the mood-lifting TOADETTE.
•	Double-E fest, with eight.  SUHWEET!
•	Lovely not-thought-about-in-ages memories jogged: MR BILL (do you remember the names of his two nemeses?*), and the lyric from “Me and Bobby McGee”, which has always stuck with me.  That lyric also triggered other lying-dormant-in-my-memory Kris Kristofferson songs that I’ve loved.
•	A pair of sweet serendipities: EDGES touching two borders, and a Boggle-style ROSS next to SUPREME.

Your clever puzzles always light me up, Joe, and once again, you delivered.  Thank you so much for this!



*Mr. Hands and Sluggo
I got the trick thanks to Bobby Mcgee. And the song fits the mood I'm in today. Thanks Joe Deeney.

>Good stuff, and at least it’s not a rebus.
So true lol

If I were a serious CRITIC, I might say NOTOKAY and give some of the slangier entries a BADEYE. 

But instead, like the Everglades, I have no r egret.
VERY clever puzzle . Good distraction from real life. Thank you NYT.
Deb, as typical, you captured the perfect thought for the day:  "at least it is not a rebus".   #thxurock

The song attributed to Janis Joplin was actually written by Kris Kristofferson and Fred Foster.  More importantly, freedom is just another word for nothing *left* to lose.  The distinction is quite important.

@ New York Times

(In hopes the poor souls, Sam, Deb, et. al tasked with us actually read this)

Here is your chance.

Did you see The Wire Season 3:  Hamsterdam?  Where the ingenious Bunny Colman (Robert Wisdom) stakes out a deserted part of Baltimore as a place to deal drugs without police interference, thereby cleaning up the street corners?  The youngsters misheard and called it "Hamsterdam" rather and Amsterdam.

Here's an internet equivalent experiment:  Make the Wordplay comment section a Hamsterdam.

We're all adults here.  Hell, I'm 72 and probably not that far off the median.  

Turn the emus off.  They are driving us all crazy.  We're copying and pasting, looking for words that might offend.

Trust us to Flag if there is a serious troll other than Barry.  (Kidding Barry, come on, now.) 

Trust us to manage our own community.

You'll be happier.  We'll be happier.  I'll be...well I'm always miserable so I don't count.

And here were are again for like the third time in two weeks -- all filled in, but... no music.  After cycling through all the answers several times, I settled on WaIU, the answer I had for 21D that was unfamiliar.  I'd heard of WII, but not WIIU, and ALIa I thought was right for 23A.  What the heck, let's change the "a" to an "I".  That was it.

This was an inspired theme.  I had three of the theme answers filled in before I realized there was more to it than I first realized.  The implied words in the answer: left, right, up, down that described the location of the word TO relative to the rest of the theme answer.  Much respect and praise to Joe Deeney.

On my first pass though, I was concerned that if (left TO) my own devices, I wouldn’t get anywhere. 

But once I got (down TO) the theme, it all came together. 

Let’s get (right TO) it, this was a lot of fun. 

What’s everyone else (up TO) later?
What a fun and surprising puzzle! It is a delight when a puzzle constructor achieves so much cleverness and creativity in a puzzle. My hat is off to you, Joe Deeney. Thanks for a great puzzle.
https://nytimesguild.org/tech/guild-builds/index.html
Once I switched GERE(s) (toGEER) I really picked up speed.

Crossnerd note…

This was a skilled build.

The four theme entries had to be inserted so the down answer pairs and the across answer pairs each had an equal letter count (to fulfill symmetry requirements).  And by the way, those four answers – NOTHING LEFT TO LOSE, COME TO THE WIRE, BRINGS UP TO SPEED, AND GET TO THE POINT – are all NYT debut answers, and worthy ones.

Also, the areas around where the gray-lettered TO’s abutted the theme answers were greatly constricted, that is, they severely limited the number of words that could work in those areas.  Yet they were, for the most part, smoothly filled.

So, deft work here, from an ace constructor!
Wonderful theme and construction.

I'm heartsick and lonely.  Forgive me, Strikers, but the puzzles are one of the few bright spots, living as we do in Deep Red, and wondering if we have years enough left in our lives to see our country emerge from darkness.   

Delightful and challenging puzzle!  It also exposes more "cultural" blanks in my life...Raves, Dungeons and Dragons, The Simpsons, Mario Bros, Miami, rock hits and rockers, ....whew.  BUT!  Jane EYRE to the rescue, wonderful memories of AMSTERDAM, Texas geography, Route 66, and things I say all the time.  
Thank you, Joe Deeney.

TO TO much.


Thanks, Joe Deeney.



I don't use apps, I print out the puzzle from my browser. But still . . . how do we support the tech guild without dissing the constructors and games staff?

Do you emu?

Oh wow, this was really fun!

I love the word ERSATZ, which I first learned from the Series of Unfortunate Events series by Lemony Snicket.

Also, congrats for the filthiest crossword answer I've ever seen, at 64D. My hat is off to you, along with the rest of my clothes.
Excellent theme, well executed, with lots of fun clues. But Mr. Bill was not “claymation” — he was only clay. He was static in every shot — only Mr. Hands moved.

Really enjoyed this, and I think the shaded squares were a great choice! They surely made it much easier to spot the trick, but, thinking about it, I don't know how long it would have taken me to get there without the shading.

Not too baffling, only one baseball reference and no TV channels composed of random initials. Any strange combinations of words/letters I just put down to 'US usage' eg 'come the wire'.

I still don't understand the use of 'themes' and manage without them, I expect I might come round to it. After doing crosswords for about 60 years without themes, it doesn't come naturally. Anyone here tried to do a cryptic puzzle? Torture.

Today is Return Day in Delaware, a tradition that dates back to (circa) 1792, whereby folks gather in Georgetown to hear the election results. There is a parade, with candidates from opposing parties riding together in carriages. After that, the party chiefs bury an actual hatchet in the town square. Then the roast ox is butchered, and everybody gets free sandwiches.

Nice use of word placement to supply directional keys. I saw  that early on, but as usual what delayed my completion was a"nit."

I originally thought the blank after Inter was alia rather than its plural alii. I had spend an extra 5 mins reviewing before I saw my  error

I got the theme -- or at least all but the last answer.  I couldn't make sense of COME under TO THE [blank].  Or COME TO under THE [blank].

DOWN, not UNDER, you idiot!!!  I think I would have gotten WIRE if I'd thought of DOWN.  But I would not have finished the puzzle.

The pop culture clues, clumped all together -- or at least it felt that way -- were, in a word, dispiriting.  I am dispirited enough right now, thank you very much, and felt no compunction to look any of the answers up.  When I fail for this reason, I plain don't care.  I really don't.

So this is the second day in a row where I really liked the theme and where I really, REALLY disliked the surrounding fill.

We like Barry as he is always correct.

We dislike puzzles with little tricks as we are bears of little brain.

ko demurs as she liked the puzzle and has a big brain.

Nothing left to lose is the mantra of the day.  I say soldier on just like in the sixties. We ended the war in Vietnam and we can drive the rats out of trumplandia.

Thank you Joe, a challenging solve
Thank you, editors, for the shaded squares. Would have been downright diabolical without them.

I loved the gimmick on this one! The directional “to”s were fun and clever. Got it in half my normal Thursday time.

:’) That being said, I would have absolutely hated it if those squares weren’t shaded, so good on whoever made that choice.

Any puzzle referencing Gloria GAYNOR is okay by me. The title of one of her best known songs is particularly apropos this week.
And any construction by Joe Deeney is sure to be fun.
Wonderful theme today! So much much-needed dopamine from that “aha” moment!
All due respect to Janis Joplin, the line (3 Down) was written by Kris Kristofferson, who passed away just this past September 28.

Being a big Janis Joplin fan, I dived into the puzzle with 3D right away.

But when NOTHING (LEFT TO) LOSE didn't fit, I tried "ANOTHER WORD", which amazingly *did* fit.

Of course, the crosses soon showed me the error of my ways, and I soon cracked the clever code of this puzzle.

Thanks, Joe Deeney!
This was a really fun one! Loved the twist and the clever clues.
Loved this!  Thank you, Joe.
8A is a great word. Someone called me a "downwardly mobile ersatz intellectual" in an online comment section once. I know what they meant, but it still makes almost no sense.
43A ??? I guess they assume all greeks are men.
The expression is “down to the wire”.

I never even noticed the shaded squares but once I realized the “Me and Bobby McGee” answer had no adjective or article, the other three long answers were a cakewalk. 

Fun!  And quick!

Am I the only one that had never heard the term, ERSATZ, before?  I spent way too long trying to figure out where I had gone wrong in that corner because I thought that couldn't possibly be the correct answer.
I done did it I finished the puzz
Fun solve today. I liked the theme, but I think I would've been hopelessly lost without the shading, so I'll add another vote in support of having added it in.

I got the theme right away because of Bobby McGee, one of the best songs and best lines ever IMHO. RIP Kris Kristofferson. All the lyrics in that short song paint such a vivid story with such brevity. Janis, of course, made it her own but recently found a YouTube video of Pink doing it justice. 
Lots of video game clues today for which I always need crosses to solve. 
WAP was solved this way too but thanks to a comment below I dove deeper in a Google search to discover that they aren’t referring to a Wireless Access Protocol.

Very entertaining puzzle today. I got the theme, but as usual, was vexed by obscure clues: if I'm old enough to know about Mel TORME, am I young enough to know about WIIU? Do I know enough about Greek to know the male plural of et alia is ALII? Spoiler alert: the answer is no. So I had ALIA crossed by WAIU. 😵‍💫
I'll be the prude today and say I didn't think the clue for the "2020 song by Cardi B" was appropriate or worthy of the Times puzzle.

Finally, a puzzle for nerds like me!

Also, if you don’t know what WAP means… don’t look it up.

really smart puzzle - i agree with the rest of the folks that i cannot imagine solving this w/o the shaded 'TO's throughout. a lot of fun with the AHA moments on this one. i was frustrated i had to look up a couple of proper nouns, even when i had >80% of the answer solved. great thursday puzzle!

Hmm, quickly glancing down it seems anything I might say was already covered.

It was a very nicely constructed puzzle.  Fun to do.  But either too easy for a Thursday or I'm getting better.  And it would have been difficult or impossible to get and enjoy the theme without circles or shading.

A good, though quick, time.  Some really clever cluing (made do).  Nice to see "ersatz".  Bad eye felt a little clunky but I'll allow it.  :)

/continued apologies to the world

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
I'm an attorney and have used et al. for decades.  It always stood for et alia.  I literally have never seen ET ALII
SUH-WEET! Loved this Thursday puzzle. Picked up the theme quickly but the puzzle as a whole was about typical difficulty for me. Really enjoyed gettable trivia like the Ozzie Smith clue. Fun one!
I think this quote from @Deb_Amlen’s column sums it up perfectly. “Good stuff, and at least it’s not a rebus.”

Great puzzle overall, my only gripe being the 7D clue. As a European, the 10-Euro bill is actually red, not pink. I also have never heard that bill being referred to as pink. The ECB (European Central Bank) also calls it red on their website.

The J Joplin Lyric is Nothin' left to lose!

NO G!!

also, too many clues these days that include references from a highly uneducated, unintelligent, fad driven lexicon that will surely disappear from the language as fast as it arrived!

Sorry to sound grumpy, I AM!!

Tuesday's tragic news demonstrate the results of the dumbing of America!

Fun little Thursday puzzle with a quick solve - the Janis Joplin lyric was an immediate reveal and helped a lot.

For some reason I had difficulty in the SW corner, choosing ROI over MOI a number of times before getting it right.

Cheers

Am I misremembering? I thought I read a comment this morning which was solely about enjoying the Cardi B song being in the crossword. There was no inappropriate language used. Now I can't find it. (Though Kate in Minnesota's comment still stands, which similarly has congratulatory text about the reference: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/431rq4?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share ) Meanwhile, there are a significant number of comments *opposed* to the inclusion that have all been left standing. I'm so confused.
Look, you can do a clever and tricky Thursday puzzle without resorting to a rebus!  Nice one, fun concept, and I like the mix of new clues for common words - and now I want ravioli for dinner.
Tulsa is NOT the Midwest! And WAP? Really NYT?! Stay classy. 🙄
I know someone who named their cat Mr Bill.  Best cat name ever. The other cat was named Sluggo.

I have never played "Mario Kart." I've never played many games at all that require hand-to-eye coordination and good reflexes ("Myst" was more my speed). My sons played a ton of games of all types, but "Mario Kart" wasn't one of them, nor were any of the several games related to it. 

Nevertheless, when required, my brain came right up with TOADETTE. I have no idea where that bit of trivia came from, but there it was.

That Miami clue was not tricky but intentionally misleading.  The neighborhood in question is in Miami Beach, not Miami. 
You could have used an accurate clue without making it any easier, do better.

To make it clear to NY-centric folks, this would be like calling Hoboken or Yonkers a neighborhood of New York City.

Tricky and fun.  Loved it. I saw what was happening with the Janis Joplin song, but not all of the theme entries came to me quite so easily. Thanks for the challenge and joy, Joe Deeney. I really needed some joy today.
SUHWEET puzzle!  Really struggled until I got to the Kristofferson song that Janis rocked.  Great theme & impressive construction!  Never could have finished without the shaded squares.
I'm guessing the  pearl clutchers are  wondering how Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion 'hit' #1 with a song about Wireless Application Protocol??
Great fun puzzle, congrats and thanks to Joe Deeney.
Sounds like a fun puzzle, but I will be taking a hiatus until the NY Times tech guild strike is over...

As a Peace Corps Volunteer in the Congo in the ‘70s, then known as Zaire, I travelled through Virunga National Park - clue 11D, many times . I was stunned and thrilled to see Virunga, considered one of the most spectacular and remote African parks, in the NTY Crossword. I’d love to know what connection Mr. Deeney has to Virunga.
Great puzzle but too many look-ups for us fogies.
Solved it in a breezy 24 minutes without lookups. Didn't realise what the gimmick was until after. I have no idea what this means for me xD

Definitely worth a rave, solving this was SUHWEET!  Especially for a Thursday, I didn’t miss the Rebuses. 😅
The shaded TO’s helped with my solve.  Favourite today : TOUPEE
Thanks Joe!

I’ve now given myself a new rule. I’m allowed a lookup if it is a natick of two cultural trivias. Inthis case it was Gaynor which allowed me to solve that whole section.
Can someone explain WIIU (I’d heard of WII) and “bringsspeed?

Looked up brospeak. No reference it comes from fraternities. That's frat talk. Comes from communities of young men. One reference was attempts to build supportive community of young Maori men. And reference to surfers.

No frat references. 

Max
Left to my own devices … I did it. Brain stretching.
Please don’t tell my Italian best friend that I tried to fit GNOCCHI in for Noodle Nuggets! 😅
Anyone who thinks a Genius Bar worker is an IT GURU, has obviously never visited a Genius Bar.
Got to this late in the day, but figuring out the theme was fun! Welcome distraction from the last couple of days. SUHWEET was last to fall, since I knew WII, but not WIIU.

Had to guess on Crooner Mel and Will from Waltons 

I don't even know who either of them are but maybe I'm getting old at 37

@Alex 

Absolutely the opposite experience for me.  My time was longer than average (probably would have been about average if I had known WIIU) and the theme was inspired.  Perhaps still in a bad mood from yesterday's news?

@Alex 

Yes a little too easy, but absolutely NOT a weak theme.  This has been a remarkable week for excellent theme constructions.  Today was the third.

/continued apologies, world

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Steve L @Steve L 
All credit to the mega-talented Kris Kristofferson, who wrote those memorable words. Still, I think it is undeniable that Janis made that song her own. It seems unutterably sad that she never saw her rendition become a #1 hit, as it was not released until after her death. May both these legends RIP!

@Steve L 

I have always enjoyed your posts.  I have learned a lot from them, and I've found you to be an engaging and interesting writer, one of my three or four favorites, in fact.

I would like to make one last attempt to heal the breach from yesterday.

I did not call you a liar.  I simply said that I found the evidence you produced in the emu experiments to not be compelling.  Nothing personal, I just think there are a lot of possibilities that weren't being tested for.  What could possibly more dispassionate than that?

Again, it's not personal.  Linus Pauling is my personal hero, a towering figure in 20th Century science.  But his later theories on Vitamin C and cancer were not convincing.  I did not believe them to be true, and I think time has backed that up.

And yet I still idolize Linus Pauling.

I don't want to die on any hill.  I really don't care if I'm right and you're wrong, or you're right  and I'm wrong.  It doesn't matter to me, since we'll probably never really have definitive proof, anyway.

And finally, with all due respect, I think your implication that because I don't believe your emu evidence, that I don't believe the earth-is-not-flat theory is just a tad ridiculous don't you think?

What do you say?  Bury the hatchet, or never talk again?

@Francis 

I'm all for burying the hatchet.  I would probably have forgotten by tomorrow who it was I was arguing with anyway.  But you're not the first person to say that this phenomenon was imaginary, and I don't get why it's so important to some people to not believe those of us who were targeted by that algorithm when it was in effect.  Especially after we stated that we did "scientific" experiments to see if our suspicions were correct, and those suspicions were confirmed.

Anyway, since supposedly the algorithm now does allow short posts for everyone, I imagine it'll be a moot point moving forward.  Unless things change back, which of course they well might.

And I'll probably just continue to do as before, just in case.

And anyway, now I'm at it with one Mr. Dave, who voiced the opinion that when people like me try to educate newbies about words they should remember for their usefulness, citing xwordinfo.com statistics, they are scolding those people.  Which of course is far from the truth...

@Darcey O’D 

I don't deny that Janis Joplin had the biggest hit with that song, and it's the version most people know best, or only know.

As a matter of personal taste, I never cared for Joplin's singing style, and I think that a lot of people who have only heard her version of the song should YouTube some other versions for comparison.  I also thought it was unuterrably sad that a person with so much potential was a heroin addict.  It would have been interesting to see how her musical style  matured as she got older.

Speaking of Joplin songs, Faith Hill recorded a country version of "Piece of My Heart" in 1993, and I suggested at the time that she rescued it.  A totally different song, in my opinion, even though it wasn't technically.  

But as I said, that's all just my opinion.

@Steve L 

Fair enough.

@Steve L Even as someone who loves Janis, I never liked her rendition of this song and, like most covers, greatly prefer the original. (Don't get me started on the Hendrix version of "All Along the Watchtower"!)

Still, in terms of crossword construction, the excursion we had to take to get from the fairly obvious NOTHING to the rest of the answer was quite clever.

@Jack McCullough 

Before I got the trick, I'd put in ANOTHER WORD...

@Steve L 

Beyond "Fair Enought".

I'm so encouraged.  This community of people of probably almost  exactly the same income level, more or less the same age group, and certainly the same in terms of ethnicity (as we are almost all English speaking which includes a lot of Europe)....

....we are able to come to some sort of polite community.

This makes me so hopeful for peace in the Middle East.

@Francis 

I have a long and painful history of short comments being autoblocked by the emus.  I don't have any data regarding adding spaces to prevent this, but I can assure you that when I pad my messages with extra words, the comments have not been blocked.  Others have suggested that it is not just comment length that is the criterion for short messages being autoblocked, but also the frequency at which short messages from the same source are submitted.  That seems like a pretty good theory, as not all my very short comments are blocked, and clearly we see short comments being published.  I am sorry you don't believer Steve L or me, but you have not done the work that we have. 

I corresponded with NYT Games Care a year ago on the emu autoblock issue.  What they did admit is that some accounts were "flagged for stringent review", but said my account was not.  The NYT would never confirm or deny that comment length was a factor in being autoblocked.  What they did say was "I am confident that the Moderators are not auto-blocking comments solely based on length".  Note the word "solely".  One could read between the lines and think length is a factor, but not the only factor in autoblocking.

I am curious that someone says the algorithm has been changed.  I wonder where that conclusion originated.

@Jim 
Re your last paragraph 
The conclusion is observational. (What else could it be?)
Barry, Steve and I have all been able to post one word comments lately, when all of us were previously prevented from doing so.

@Vaer 

Thanks, Vaer.  I'll test the waters myself then, and see how it goes.

@Jim 

I really appreciate your reply.  

I got caught up in something again, not sure how, but I'm fully willing to accept your word that your experience says it's true, even if mine does not.  We could bogh the right. We could neither br right.  We don't really know because the NYT won't tell us.

And, ffter all, what's the difference?

The whole point is that the sytem is riddled with speculation and uncertainty, and should be an embarrassment for an organization the staure of the New York Times.

@Vaer 
Until I saw Steve L’s post today about a possible change in “the algorithm” I had not heard this discussed….I may have missed something. OTOH, I almost wrote in the other day when I saw BA using such short posts and getting these in. For example, when he made that remark, “Sir, this is a Wendy’s” it was perfect and right to the point….a lot of added verbiage would have taken away from the moment. If this change is for real, it would be a real plus and I will enjoy not adding all the dashes at the end of my posts.

@Francis,

I hope that I’m speaking for a lot of us when I say that I’m glad to see that you and @Steve L have resolved your dispute. And like you, whenever I see a move toward accommodation from anywhere, I also think about how peace in the Middle East is still possible.  

Hope I’m not over sharing, but after Tuesday, I think we’re going to need a lot of understanding and patience and kindness and respect for the next four years. IMHO, that’s our best hope for living life. It’s how I will try to handle my sadness for my country. 

Thank you, Francis and Steve L.

@Steve L 

You're not the scolder. 

Not all xword citations are 
scolding.

It happens.

@Jonathan I have found that there probably won't be a rebus if there are special squares (shaded, circled, etc.).  

This might help you in detecting a rebus next time :)

@Alex 

But sometimes the circles or shaded squares are the ones you put the rebuses (rebi?) in. See last week's (very enjoyable) moon puzzle.
@Sarah very true. I should have specified that it's not usually the case if there are several special squares, especially not in long downs and acrosses
@Alex I guess that's true, but I was just thinking that what I knew had to be the answer, with a few clues, did not fit, so rebus was my first option.

Jonathan,

I also start with "If the correct answer doesn't fit, look for a rebus." It's a great place to start, especially on Thursdays. But today, early on, when I had TOUPEE (with the shaded TO) at 16A and SPEED at the end of 18A, I quickly saw the non-rebus solution. As others mentioned earlier, without the shading it would have taken longer to see it.

@Marshall Walthew 
Yep, hands up for geek. Sorry IT people, you’ve helped me out on more than one occasion.
@Striker Ha ha! If anyone missed your point, there’s this: (Testing a short post!) https://tinyurl.com/ymyxjjms

@LC 
I'm good.

@LC 
Not jubilant, but definitely relieved.
@Asher I had to look it up when I first started solving puzzles.  It’s the masculine form of et alia. They’re both plurals.

@Asher. To expand on the subject. “Et alia” is used for “and other things”. “Et alii”, commonly abbreviated “et. al.” is found in bibliographies and is plural masculine gendered, readable “and others (people)”. The abbreviated form could also encompass “et aliae” the feminine plural.
@Asher That was what slowed me up as well.  A real "TIL," which is a good thing.
@Ιασων My streak would be 200 today! Not playing, and may cancel my subscription depending on the outcome of the strike.

@A.B. nevermind, I Googled it. First I'm hearing about it.

@Hope Oh awesome thanks,  Hope!

@A.B. 
I hear it’s partly about time off for pet bereavement, scents in the break room, and trigger warnings.

@Hardroch 

That's awfully harsh. Sure, there are aspects of their demands that I personally feel are far-fetched. But that's beside the point.

The big issues are *pay equity* and, more fundamentally, that despite forming and voting in a nationally-recognized union two years ago, the NYT has yet to sign a contract with said union. 

(I still can't wrap my head around these particular tech workers needing to unionize, but that too is besides the point - at this point.)

@Hardroch could be about anything. Nothing we take for granted was given freely by employers because they care. It was fought for on the streets of Chicago and elsewhere. Crossing a picket line to play a game seems disrespectful. https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/m0023gm2
@Marilyn sorry it's an S .Makes leaves for autumn leaves and leaves the white house???

Moving the S makes the words FALL and LEAVES, which are timely for Autumn.

@The Original RH

@PR Betz  What in this puzzle seems extremely hip and au courant? Certainly not the jazz musician who died in the 90s, the baseball player inducted over 20 years ago into the hall of fame. Was it the gaming console from 2012? The Mario character who has been around for decades?

@Amanda
Toadette. WAP. WIIU.

@Elke 

I think Amanda's point is not that there's nothing recent, but rather that it's well balanced with older things.  

As we get older, it's unreasonable to think that the puzzle should contain only older things.  We have to keep up with the times.  You don't have to know everything, but the crosses should usually help.

And it's probably best you're not familiar with WAP, or what it stands for.
@Steve L  Yes but I also wouldn’t consider a gaming console that’s more than a decade old and a worldwide hit song from 4 years ago to be super hip.
@Amanda, not to mention the SNL character from, I’m guessing, 47  years ago.

@Amanda 

Many people of a certain age--I'm 68, so I know this includes many in my demographic--aren't aware of ANY hits of the past 20-30 years, no matter how big they are.  Yet they can rattle off every doo-wop or 60s Beatlemania era song, or folk-rock 70s song, depending on their age.  Everyone thinks the music they grew up with is the best music.

Doing crosswords is one way I keep up on some of the modern songs, games, movie stars, etc.  (I also think I keep my eyes and ears open a bit more than some others.)

WAP could have sold 20 million copies, and a lot of my age group would never have heard of it.  My kids were surprised I knew who Chappell Roan was...

@PR Betz 
Kids these days and their governesses.
@MDB I love how you think NYT makes Thursday puzzles "for the masses"

And there were a few too many pop culture references for my liking, though I suppose Janis Joplin could be included in there too, she says, slightly abashed.

"Suh-weet" was said a lot in the late 2000s/early 2010s and was spelled the same way online. I'd say it's slang, which we see often in crosswords.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: Actually there were two puzzles with a varied form of clues. Each of them used just a single letter as the clues for the theme answers, but with a completely different trick. First - a Wednesday from May 5, 1999 by Lois Sidway. Some clue/answer examples: "U." COMMUNITYCENTER "C." CANOPENER "A." THELASTOFSHEILA Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/5/1999&g=20&d=A And then, a Wednesday from July 30, 2003 by Alan Jay Weiss. Four 15 letter theme answers. The theme clues and answers: "W." NICKNAMEFORBUSH "X." ILLITERATESMARK "Y." COMMUNITYCENTER "Z." COSTAGRAVASFILM Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/30/2003&g=46&d=A Thought it was quite amazing that both of those puzzles managed to clue COMMUNITYCENTER with a single letter using a completely different trick. I'm done. ..

@Lewis My father’s name is Bill, and when I lived in London in the ‘70s my parents came to visit me and Dad rented a car. As we navigated the (then unknown in the US) FIFO roundabouts in the left lane and Dad was swearing a blue streak, I began yelling, “Oh no, Mr. Bill!”

We were all laughing so hard I’m still amazed that we lived to tell the tale.

@Mean Old Lady That's where I get my kicks. I mean - you reminded me of an old favorite song and I stumbled across a puzzle with ROUTESIXTYSIX as the theme. That was the last theme answer and all the other theme answers referenced it. e.g. "Colorful natural attraction along 114 across." PAINTEDDESERT Some other theme answers: THEMOTHERROAD GATEWAYARCH CADILLACRANCH But the most amazing thing was the clue for ROUTESIXTYSIX, which was: "Theme of this puzzle, which winds its way nearly 2,500 miles through all the shaded squares herein :" And the shaded squares (all parts of a longer answer), in an angular line from the lower left to the upper right were: CA, AZ, NM, TX, OK, KS, MO, IL. Just amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/15/2022&g=114&d=A ..

@Mean Old Lady 

Sending you an internet hug.
@Mean Old Lady with you in spirit

@Mean Old Lady 

Heartsick describes it perfectly. Hugs.

commentBody:
@Rich in Atlanta 

I remember that one. Impressive.

@Mean Old Lady Living in a deep blue area and trust me, we are also devastated and although not lonely, I've noticed many of us are keeping more to ourselves this week. It's a difficult time. Just trying to enjoy the little things in life, like today's puzzle and comments, and taking courage from all those who came before us and endured worse.

@Rich in Atlanta
I remember that one well!  Love anything Route 66. Used to live near Cadillac Ranch. Wasn’t that long ago that I stayed in an awesome Rte66 themed motel in Santa Rosa with a giant Clyde the camel out front.  Tried to find it again but sadly Clyde disappeared.

@Mean Old Lady also heartsick, but at least not too lonely, living in a blue spot surrounded by deepest red. Although many people who work here live in a red area, so we still have to be careful about what we say sometimes.

@Katie 
Agreed, ERSATZ is a fine word. I knew it from reading of Germans drinking ersatz coffee during WWII, made of acorns and such. Of course they were destined to lose!
@Katie wow! I had to scroll down below Wireless Access Protocol in Google to figure that one out!
@Bill MacDonald Good point! I didn't remember that.

@Bill MacDonald 

Very fair point!  And one of a scant few times I can remember such a criticism being accurate.

You're right.  Claymation is a thing (animation method) and he was merely (easily damaged) clay.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Jane Wheelaghan 
I like doing cryptic crosswords with my wife.  It's fun to do them together; an opportunity to brainstorm.  Often we'll figure out the right answer and then need to spend a few minutes to figure out how the clue is related to the answer.
Not too long ago, an English-American friend gave us a book of British cryptics (from The Telegraph).  Now that's torture!  
It gives me empathy, however, for the non-Americans who work the NYTimes puzzle.  I do hope that you'll learn to love the themes.  They're the best part!
@Nancy I agree, there were two too many clues about video games or other pop culture, but I really enjoyed the crossword otherwise, very clever and fun to solve!

@dk 

Thank you for paying proper homage to our brother and keeper, may he forever be exalted.

We are ever humble before you.

Slight suggestion:  I think Trumpsylvania has a nice ring, don't you?
@Vaer this song also came up in my mystery lyrics quiz yesterday!
@Vaer Listen to the Cake version for a rock n roll experience.

Crossword clues and answers need not cover every possibility. One example is enough. BROSPEAK is *a* Greek language. I'm sure "they" know women also have a Greek language. https://thesororitylife.com/sorority-terminology/

@Lois 
I was a fraternity "BRO" and I can assure you that we didn't SPEAK any differently than any other college student...apart from learning Robert's Rules of Order.
@Barry Not to speak for Lois, but it's possible to be irritated over the use of unnecessarily exclusive language without attacking the validity of a clue.

Josh,

BROSPEAK purports to describe 
how BROS SPEAK. 

How is that unnecessarily exclusive?
@Valerie The answer when parsed with the location of the "to" is: comes [down] to the wire

@Valerie  Look at the grid again and the shaded squares are directional: "to" is below or "down" the answer, so the expression is "come (down) to the wire." Another of the theme entries is "get (right to) the point." Please read the Wordplay, The Crossword Column that appears in the Gameplay section of the NYT. It explains it well.

@BigRob

Yes, you are the only one.

@BigRob 
The term was used in Germany during WW2 with the meaning 'substitute' as when acorns were used to make ersatz coffee. Usually implies a poor substitute.

@Cathall 
While some might think your comment was rude, I just take it as a pretty funny joke. Another example of why allowing short comments to pass “the algorithm” (per Steve L) will only enhance this forum.

@BigRob

I only know this word because of A Series of Unfortunate Events.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Good, so we're all agreed.  @BigRob was the only one.

;)

/I always liked the word and it's good to see it

/continued apologies, world

@BigRob I'd heard it before, but most memorably on The Big Bang Theory from Leonard's mother, in the most withering tone possible.

@Mark

@Mark

Even if I didn't, I know (a) enough about Nintendo consoles and controllers to get a general idea, and (b) that WII is regularly an answer in the crossword.

commentBody: @Goes without saying nobody ever uses et alii. Et Alia means 'and others' whether they are things or people.  Show me a single citation that uses et alii.
Allen, Here are a couple of citations. They're not citations of cases, but I hope you will still accept them. https://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/et+alii

@Phil According to Wikipedia. "It is the second-smallest note measuring 127 × 67 mm with a pink colour scheme." However, in the same article, they say "The ten euro note is the second smallest at 127 millimetres (5.0 in) × 67 millimetres (2.6 in) with a red colour scheme." https://tinyurl.com/2s39sxs4 In the same article, in the picture of the note given, it looks to be in the pink family to me. Or maybe red. After all, what is pink other than pale red?
@Medhat Eldeeb everything new is a fad until it sticks around :)
@Michael omg thanks a million. I couldn't understand core down to the wire!!!!

🤷‍♀️

G,

Sorry. I don't recall the one you recall.

@Eva H., 

I grew up in southwest Missouri, about 100 miles from Tulsa. Missouri, Kansas, and yes, Oklahoma are in the Midwest.

@Eva H.

@BamBam A while ago the Times (intentionally) named the best pizza in NY to be at Razza. It’s across the Hudson River in Jersey City, NJ. Maybe a trend? https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/dining/razza-pizza-review-jersey-city.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare
@Jerry Z I can't take credit for that clue, someone on the editorial team came up with that one

@Joe Deeney I was hoping you had visited Virunga. With its 14,000 foot active volcanoes and the last large population of mountain gorillas, hence the clue, it is the oldest national park in Africa, established by the Belgians a 100 years ago. Kudos to that someone on the editorial team.
@Crevecoeur the WIIU was the successor console to the WII.

@MB - You need to search more thoroughly. BROSPEAK: Alternative forms bro speak, bro-speak Etymology From bro +‎ -speak. Noun brospeak (uncountable) (rare) Speech characteristic of bros and bro culture. BRO: bro (plural bros) (slang) Brother (a male sibling). My mom took my lil' bro to soccer practice now and she wanted me to pick him up. (slang) Brother (a comrade or friend; one who shares one’s ideals). Bro, you good? You've been lookin' kinda out of it lately. (slang) Brother used to address a male. Ayo, bro, sorry to bother you but I think I accidentally backed up into your car: could we exchange information? *******(slang) A frat boy or someone who espouses the >>>>>fraternity bro culture.<<<<<<< (slang, derogatory, usually in compounds) Someone, usually male, who aggressively evangelizes a person, concept or technology. https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/brospeak

CaptainQ,

Right back atcha!

@MB 

Thus the question mark in the clue.

Greek fraternity brothers are certainly "bros".

Bro speak is slang for male buddy bonding language.

It's not a huge leap, and the question mark makes it completely fair, if not outright obvious....
